content:
I was watching this thread because I think I know what could be going on, but needed confirmation that the messages are indeed being sent and not just being saved in a Sent folder… :)

Something that could be causing this is Thunderbird somehow saving your drafts in Outbox, which is a special folder in Local Folders it uses to keep messages waiting to be sent. Now, I don't think you're really saving your drafts there and the possible explanation may end up being a little funnier, but just to be sure, what are your account Copies & Folders settings for Drafts? Where are your drafts supposed to be stored according to those settings?

If they're being saved in the right Drafts folder, what could be going on here is that somehow (presumably a bug) has caused that folder to be flagged as if it was an Outbox folder, thus causing the strange behaviour you're observing…

Install the following add-on in order to be able to see and change folder flags:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/

After installing it, in Thunderbird right-click on the folder that's being used to store your drafts, choose Properties and select the Flags tab. Does it show the Outbox flag ticked there? If so, uncheck it, click OK, and that should fix the problem.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Does the user name/email address in the 'From' section of your email (1) match the User name in your SMTP Settings (2) and the email address in your Server Settings (3)?

1 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the name of the account through which you are sending the email. On the right is the return email address called 'Email Address' unless you have put another email address in 'Reply-to Address'.

2 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings/Outgoing Server (SMTP). Highlight the server through which you are sending the email and the User Name is displayed at the bottom. It can be changed using the 'Edit' button.

3 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the 'Server Settings' under the account through which you are sending the email. The email address is in the 'User Name' field.

It's not unusual for an Email provider to change the servers - so doing that with the latest release of their details is worth doing.

As soon as you said 'elderly friend', I felt the hairs on the back of my neck stand up. I look over a couple of elderly people's computers and, amongst other things, the amount of times they click-drag folders and files across their email accounts is frightening - with consequences that have me frequently baffled.

I'm not sure I'll be able to help but there have been a couple of posts recently where people have complained that functionality has been compromised - and it's become apparent a few posts in that the file structure is something worthy of a horror movie plot.

Before someone could help, I think we need a screenshots of the file structure (with any personal info like email addresses) removed. Is this an IMAP or POP account? How many of each? Thunderbird is on a computer?? Which version of Thunderbird are you using? Which Operating System are you using?

We can manually delete some folders on the HD but it really needs to be seen what the extent of the problem is first.

content:
Is this folder a folder that is stored on my PC rather than somewhere in Thunderbird?

Yes.

Can I move my archived folders (sorted by year) into "Local Folders" and will that improve Thunderbirds performance?

Don't know whether it will improve performance, but it will sure improve the integrity of your mail. Thunderbird stores the contents of each folder in a single mbox file in the filesystem. Keeping your mail stored in huge folders with lots of messages is a bad idea.

You may also want to check this:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages

content:
Thunderbird pri každom spustení kontroluje stav synchronizácie medzi svojim úložiskom správ a poštovým serverom a potom uskutoční všetky potrebné prenosy (stiahne nové správy zo servera, zmaže na serveri všetky správy zmazané v počítači atď.). Kým je Thunderbird spustený a má prístup na Internet, vykonáva nepretržite synchronizáciu s poštovým serverom. Ak internetové pripojenie stratí, spustí synchronizáciu pri obnovení spojenia.

Nesynchronizované správy sú v Thunderbirde stále dostupné. Jediný rozdiel je v tom, že stiahnutá nie je celá správa, ale iba jej „hlavička“. (Hlavička správy obsahuje odosielateľa, príjemcu, predmet, dátum a čas atď. – všetko okrem tela správy.) Telo správy sa nesťahuje, kým nekliknete na správu v zozname správ (čiže pokiaľ nie ste momentálne pripojení na Internet, nemôžete si správu prečítať).

Keď je tých správ obrovské množstvo, tak synchronizácia prebieha aj niekoľko hodín (dní). Časom sa všetky údaje zosynchronizujú. Kliknite na spodnú lištu Thunderbirdu a pozrite si "Správcu činnosti".
creator: Ansamb

content: Synchronizace je dokončená, Thunderbird tvrdí, že je účet aktuální. Přesto tyto e-maily zůstaly s datem první synchronizace, při níž se objevily jako nově doručené, přestože jsou staré (nejstarší je z 2010).
creator: vaclav.mika

content:
Kliknite na priečinok "Doručená pošta" pravým tlačidlom myši a vyberte "Vlastnosti" - kliknite na dlaždicu "Opraviť priečinok"

Kliknite na spodnú lištu Thunderbirdu a pozrite si v "Správcovi činnosti" priebeh opravy.
creator: Ansamb

content: Průběh trval necelou hodinu, výše uvedené e-maily změnily datum a čas na aktuální synchronizaci.
creator: vaclav.mika

content:
This being an IMAP account, you may try removing the account (I'd remove both account info and message data in this case), and set it up in Thunderbird again, indeed. Everything stored on the server should be back when Thunderbird synchronises with the server after setting up the account, but make a backup copy of your profile folder first, just in case.

BUT…

The alert you're getting is weird because you would typically get that alert as a result of having misconfigured Thunderbird to use the wrong mail server, which causes Thunderbird to not be able to find the certificate it expects to find for that kind of server… but you appear to be using the right server for a Gmail account, which means you may encounter the same problem again after re-creating the account in Thunderbird with the same settings…

So you may try re-creating the account in Thunderbird, but I'd like you to post a screenshot of both your incoming and outgoing server settings first, so I may check that everything there is correct.
creator: DavidGG

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

Removing the account from Thunderbird merely deletes what Thunderbird stores locally on your computer for that account, not what's on the server.

You only posted the incoming server settings, not the outgoing ones, but they look right to me, so if you have incoming mail problems, re-creating the account in Thunderbird is what I would try next, yes.

content:
You only need to backup what the article says, which I'll link here for reference because the link you posted is malformed:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

The other profile folder you see under a Local folder is for temporary and cache files, and is kept in a separate directory precisely so you can backup the relevant data without including that.

You may want to backup the whole Thunderbird folder two levels above the profile folder, but definitely not the other part.
creator: DavidGG

The other profile folder you see under a Local folder is for temporary and cache files, and is kept in a separate directory precisely so you can backup the relevant data without including that. You may want to backup the whole Thunderbird folder two levels above the profile folder, but definitely not the other part.

Thank you - that helps a ton !

For reference, I've now figured out that my problem trying to migrate from one computer to another (that got me on this path in the first place) is that "way back when" I was short of disk space so I moved the Local POP3 folders to a different drive that had space. You can do that deep in the settings of an email account but if you forget to also back up that folder you can lose a lot. PEBKAC of course.

content:
- once installed to c, exit thunderbird - locate accounts in profile - imapmail for imap accounts and mail folder for pop accounts - copy the accounts to drive e - start thunderbird and click account settings and then server settings - click link at bottom line that points to account and change to the drive e setting - close and restart thunderbird and all should be ok you can now delete those folders in the C profile

creator: orangewatchcompany

content:
Yes, To ensure we get this right, here are steps to move an account to E: - exit thunderbird - copy the webmail.highway1.com.au to drive E - feel free to rename if desired, as name is not important - start thunderbird, click 'account settings>server settings - click the browse button at the side of Local directory, and then click to the drive E profile and click ok - thunderbird will close and restart - once all is okay, you can delete the webmail.highway1.com.au from Local Directory

This works because Thunderbird is intentionally stupid. People have problems when they think thunderbird 'looks' for the account. Instead, it must be explicitly told all of this.  :)
creator: davidsk

content:
Looks like your outgoing (SMTP) server uses a form of authentication known as "POP before SMTP", where the mail client (Thunderbird) has to authenticate with the incoming (POP) server first in order to be able to use the SMTP server. The POP authentication remains valid for a few minutes.

You may be able to solve the problem by checking for new mail more frequently (e.g. every 5 mins, maybe 10), or manually checking for mail right before sending.
creator: DavidGG

content: Well, I don't know your specifics, but generally, when a person changes from one email provider to another, the only way existing messages will get to the new server is if the user manually forwards them. Email providers do not usually see it as their responsibility to do that. Your new email provider sets up the account with the new email id and waits for it to be populated by incoming mail to that address. What am I missing here?
creator: davidsk

content: Those WERE my specifics! I'm talking about all my folders all being emptied of all saved emails over years all at once! That shouldn't happen regardless of anything!
creator: aerotugg1

content:
The most likely scenario is that your account is IMAP, and you did modify the existing account instead of creating a new one for the new server. The new server has no messages yet, hence it did erase all your mail which did previously exist on the old server. This isn't Thunderbird's fault, it's just how IMAP works. You probably should have spent a little more time prior to the switch of the account to determine what needs to be done to preserve your messages.

All that is my best guess, since you provided virtually no details about your setup. Also guessing, you don't have backups of your Thunderbird profile.
creator: christ1
